articles.content:
How 'Fascism' became a meme 
         By Brittany Luse, Alexis Williams, Barton Girdwood, Neena Pathak, Mika Ellison  
        
           Monday, November 10, 2025 • 3:00 AM EST 
        
        
      

         It's hard to spend time online without encountering someone calling President Trump a fascist. Trump himself has used the word against his own opponents. Others have used the word to denounce Skinny-Tok as "body fascism." But why are Americans so willing to use the word? And is its ubiquity making it lose its meaning? In this episode, Brittany is joined by Nicholas Ensley Mitchell, a professor of education and policy at the University of Kansas. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Episode Highlights Why "fascism" has become a go-to term LUSE: What are people trying to point out when they return to the term "fascism"? What are they really trying to say? MITCHELL: Danger. Fascism as a meme is closely synonymous with danger. [It communicates that] there is a threat and it's an active threat. Whenever you call someone a fascist, you call a group a fascist, you are not just saying that, "Oh, they just exist." No. These guys are trying to take something away from you. They are trying to repress you. So it's a recognition that there is danger, and it's coming after me. It's an ingrained alarm in American culture. And I think despite all the changes in how it's been used in American history, it retains that sense of urgency. That this is not something to sleep on. The keys to fighting fascism could be in American history MITCHELL: When you think of Jim Crow as fascism, then that makes Black history and the resistance to Jim Crow an example of how you fight fascism. We have this image of the Civil Rights Movement: the bus boycotts, Rosa Parks is tired so she won't give up her seat, Martin Luther King gives a speech where he just talks about the content of character. What it actually was, in many regards, and how segregationists saw it, was a revolt. Black people have been calling — I mean, we've been talking about fascism [since] the thirties. Langston Hughes, he says in 1937, "We Negroes in America do not have to be told what fascism is [in action]. We know." 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Is "fascism" the right term for our current moment?   LUSE:  [Responding to Mitchell saying "cultural upheaval" more aptly describes our current moment]  I mean, when you say "cultural upheaval," that phrase is so neutral. I think that makes sense. But I will say, that when you say that to me, I understand why some people, regardless of where they are in the political spectrum, would reach for fascism because "social upheaval" doesn't satisfy the feeling of fear and discomfort that I think many people feel when these big moments of change are happening. MITCHELL: I would agree. And I think that's why you see this term get used so much. I think being afraid and being anxious, that is a normal reaction. That is not people overreacting. Because [cultural upheaval] is the environment into which European fascism emerged. But also, it's the environment that the civil rights movement really worked its power to force America to be a democracy. That is the outcome of the civil rights movement. I use the term cultural upheaval because these are tectonic shifts happening in the culture. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       
         
         Transcript 
         BRITTANY LUSE, HOST:   Over the past few weeks, we've been breaking down the history, subtext and evolving meanings of the buzzwords you hear all over the news and social media. This is the ABCs of the culture wars. Our final word is F for fascism. NICHOLAS ENSLEY MITCHELL: We don't have a lot of terms in American society that are kind of cross-political, cross-cultural. Fascism is one them. LUSE: That's Professor Nicholas Ensley Mitchell. He teaches education theory, policy and practice at the University of Kansas. And he's right. You hear this word all over the political spectrum - from the press account of California Governor Gavin Newsom calling Homeland Security adviser Stephen Miller a fascist in all caps on X, to then-presidential nominee Donald Trump calling former Vice President Kamala Harris a fascist. (SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING) PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP: She's a Marxist, communist, fascist. LUSE: So how do we make sense of the word fascist being thrown around like this? Well, Professor Mitchell has been writing about the history of the word, and he's offering a perspective that I haven't really heard in mainstream conversations about fascism. MITCHELL: So I think we can talk about this really as just a meme, in the sense that we talk about other memes on the internet. Fascism - it's a succinct way of talking about an oppressive cultural regime or government or, you know, even vibe. LUSE: Yeah. I mean, to your point, it's not just being used in a political context. Like, I've seen people accuse some influencers of, quote-unquote, "body fascism" when they talk about weight loss and body image. You know, it shows up in a lot of different parts of American discourse. MITCHELL: And the reason for that is really tied up in American history. I mean, going really back into the - to the Second World War, you know, which is this conflict that just defines America. LUSE: What Professor Mitchell means is that modern American identity was crystallized in opposition to fascism. I mean, if you grew up in the American school system, I'm sure you can see the image right now of American soldiers heroically going to Europe to fight the Nazis in World War II. (SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING) FRANKLIN D ROOSEVELT: Never before has there been a greater challenge to life, liberty and civilization. LUSE: They were fighting against fascism, against an ideology seen as counter to the American ideals of freedom and democracy. (SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING) ROOSEVELT: We believe that the Nazis and the fascists have asked for it, and they're going to get it. MITCHELL: Fascism is explicitly authoritarian. It is chauvinistic. It is sexist, and it is ultra nationalistic and racist. It's very obsessed with us and them. It's not just government. It's a full cultural movement. It is obsessed with aesthetics, how people dress, how people talk, symbols on buildings, the layout of cities, you know, ghettos versus where everybody else could go. LUSE: Other scholars define fascism as a dictatorship with enthusiastic public support and say that fascism can develop in a democracy when the people start to feel their leader doesn't have enough power to avert a perceived national crisis. And, you know, these definitions might stir a feeling in you right now. But there's an important difference between feeling that something is fascist and a formal system of fascism. MITCHELL: You know, in a democratic pluralistic society, you know, meaning is determined by individuals. You know, we determine meaning for ourselves. In a fascist society, meaning is determined by the state. They tell you what the history means. They tell you what everything means. LUSE: And in Professor Mitchell's essay, titled "Want To Learn How To Respond To Fascism? Study Black History," he lays out why he thinks American history showcases this country's much older relationship with fascism, long before Nazism and World War II. MITCHELL: Fascists are always concerned with, like, let's have this mythic past so then we can control who we are and say who belongs and who doesn't belong and whose grievances and histories are real and who's are just complaining. In my experience, they all try to go for a very sanitized history, rather than what I call the messy truth. LUSE: Today, we're getting into why Professor Mitchell thinks this country needs to deal with what he calls its own fascist past. MITCHELL: And that's the messy truth of American history. It's a lot of contradictions. (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC) LUSE: Hello, hello. I'm Brittany Luse, and you're listening to IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR, a show about what's going on in culture and why it doesn't happen by accident. (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC) LUSE: You know, we're going to get into the exact polling in a second, but a big headline from the past year is that a majority of Americans - particularly Democratic voters - have said that they see Trump as a fascist or dictator-like. I mean, if you did a quick search right now, you can find think piece on think piece arguing, you know, whether the country is sliding into fascism. I know a lot of people have concerns about our current moment, but is fascism the right descriptor for it? MITCHELL: Oh, that's a huge question. LUSE: (Laughter) Sorry. Sorry to lay that on you. MITCHELL: Oh, well, I mean, it is not surprising to me that people use that term because this term has been used various ways. I mean, of course, Nixon was called a fascist. Reagan was called a fascist. Obama was called a fascist... LUSE: Yeah. MITCHELL: ...For the Affordable Care Act. But also during the war - you know, in the war on terror, the term Islamic fascism was so common. LUSE: Right, right. MITCHELL: And that happens exactly when social media is starting to take off. That's early Facebook, later early Twitter - or X now. LUSE: Well, to kind of think in terms of today, a widely talked about poll from October 2024 taken right before the presidential election found that 49% of Americans identified Trump as a fascist. To your point about this being a political meme, 22% also described Vice President Harris as a fascist. Now, in April of this year, in another poll, 41% of Americans strongly defined Trump as a, quote, "dangerous dictator," compared with 27% who strongly defined him as a, quote, "strong leader who should be given power to restore America's greatness." What do these snapshots say about the state of this country? MITCHELL: For the past 25 years, we have been in this really intense cultural battle over who are we and who do we want to be? And we've had so much dynamic change in the past 25 years from, you know, Bush, 9/11 war on terror. And then you get the first Black president. And then, you know, Trump, from completely outside of the political world, he comes in, and then that brings his own - its own sort of upheaval. Me, personally, I think that when historians look back on this era, we're going to look at kind of like the twin - like, the twin poles of the change of whatever comes after this, it's going to be Obama and Trump. LUSE: Yeah. MITCHELL: Like... LUSE: And they also represent - they - even just in the popular imagination, they represent, in some ways, things that can feel very polar opposite to many people. MITCHELL: Yes. LUSE: And they are side by side. MITCHELL: And who gets to have power? And, you know... LUSE: Yeah. MITCHELL: ...Who, you know, that - you know, Obama, this, you know - and not just for him being, you know - him being African American. He's also not - he's an academic. He's very new to politics. And then you have Trump. Trump is a businessman, and he was a media figure, very kind of pop cultural figure. Of course, both of - you know, these aren't the first academic president and, you know, Trump's not the first... LUSE: Or the first, like, celebrity president, either, yeah. MITCHELL: So with all that change and all that clash, it does not surprise me that people were out there calling Obama a fascist, and it does not surprise me that people are calling Trump a fascist because that meme is our - it's our stand-in for there's a lot of change, and it's scaring some people. LUSE: So is kind of calling President Trump fascist, is this kind of - is this just like political name-calling or something adjacent to that, that may need some more teasing out? MITCHELL: I think it's the second one. We're grappling - I think Americans are grappling with how to make sense of a lot of this. So, like, there's one really key fact that I think is relevant to any discussion about Trump - and I don't know why more people don't talk about it. Every single one of Donald Trump's electoral coalitions was multiracial. It was multiclass. I was multi-ethnic. Multiracial fascism is not something that happens. LUSE: I mean, it - I know what you're saying is true. We have reported on these things... MITCHELL: Yes, you all have, yeah. LUSE: ...On this show before, but pulling just that fact out for a second and looking at it, it - I mean... MITCHELL: So... LUSE: It's like - it feels like you hit reset on my brain. MITCHELL: Trump didn't just have one multiracial coalition. He had three. LUSE: Yeah. MITCHELL: In the third election, he picks up a third of the non-white vote. You can't ignore that in any of these conversations, but a lot of people do. LUSE: Yeah. I guess maybe part of what you're saying then is that fascism doesn't quite fit as a descriptor because Trump has a diverse coalition backing him and that, you know, the idea of a multiracial coalition doesn't really fit with the definitions of fascism. And maybe there's a different word that might fit better. MITCHELL: So it's like, when you put it all together, what does this say about who we are - and into that uncertainty. LUSE: Yeah. MITCHELL: That's where you're going to see fascism get a lot of track in the popular culture as a meme for describing what they're seeing. (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC) LUSE: Coming up - the words Professor Mitchell thinks define this moment. Stay with us. (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC) LUSE: Thinking about fascism again and in the broader sense, not just in the way that people are maybe using it to describe a swift political change that feels wrong to them, many Americans think of fascism as something very un-American. Not just, like, against American values, but more specifically, something that has happened before in history, but never here. But you argue that America has a strong history of fascism in Jim Crow and in American segregation. Tell me more about that. MITCHELL: Sure. We have this interesting and very impoverished view of Jim Crow. We'll talk about it as oh, it was separate water fountains and separate schools. No, it was that, but it was also ghettoizing people. It was brutalizing them. It was state-sanctioned murder and terrorism. You know, you get, like, you know, events like Red Summer where you have nationwide race riots. And then, of course, you get probably, you know, the most famous of those being the Tulsa Race Massacre in 1921. If I put those sorts of things in a European context, we would call those pogroms. LUSE: Yeah, yeah. For those who don't know, pogroms were violent attacks or riots targeting Jewish people by both Russians and Germans in the 19th and early 20th century. MITCHELL: You know, so you have these parallels between what's happening with Jewish people and minorities in, you know, Nazi Germany and in Europe and what's happening in the United States. It's the sort of thing that inspires the Nazis. The Nazis are looking at American eugenics for inspiration for their own murderous eugenics programs. LUSE: And just to lay out our timeline here - the Jim Crow period in the United States was from 1877 to around the 1950s. Nazism and its eugenics program really took off in the 1930s, when Jim Crow laws were still in effect. MITCHELL: You know, there's a great book, "Hitler's American Model," that gets into how much the antisemitic laws were directly inspired by the Jim Crow laws, and they have the - one of the big justices, rather, of the Nazi regime saying in the book - and it's me paraphrasing - this set of laws is great for us. The only problem is that it considers Jewish people to be white. LUSE: I mean, I think, you know, some people might argue that Jim Crow isn't exactly quote-unquote, "fascism," but in your view, why do you think it's important to frame Jim Crow like this? MITCHELL: When you think of Jim Crow as fascism, then that makes Black history and the resistance to Jim Crow an example of how do you fight fascism. We have this image of the Civil Rights Movement that, you know, you get the bus boycotts, Rosa Parks is tired so she won't give up her seat. LUSE: Right. MITCHELL: Martin Luther King gives a speech where he just talks about the content of character... LUSE: Right. MITCHELL: ...Versus what it actually was in many regards, and honestly, how segregationists saw it, that it was a revolt. Black people have been calling - I mean, we have been talking about fascism in the '30s. You know, Langston Hughes, he says in 1937, we Negroes in America do not have to be told what fascism is. We know. LUSE: So even the conversation we are having right now is not new. This is (inaudible). MITCHELL: Yeah, it's about a hundred years old. I want to say - I mean, Du Bois linked Jim Crow and fascism and, like, imperialism. But I think the big takeaway for me when I was talking about understanding Jim Crow as a form of fascism and why is that important, it's because in America, we have this view of American democracy as these ancient pillars driven into the ground. But if you're going to be bluntly honest, can you call yourself a democracy if a bunch of your people can't vote because of the color of their skin? LUSE: It's a fair question. MITCHELL: Or because of their sex? So to me - and I agree with the scholars who, you know, argue this - that America doesn't become a liberal democracy until 1965... LUSE: When the Voting Rights Act is passed. MITCHELL: ...When the Voting Rights Act is passed. So then in that sense, American liberal democracy is very fragile. It's new. Black people and non-white people and also white people across the political spectrum who were, they're down with this - they're down with the Civil Rights Movement - so conservative, liberal, all of that, they joined this revolt to overthrow this system. It's a multiracial creation. It's a multi-ethnic creation. It's a multipolitical creation. Republicans and Democrats, liberals and conservatives and progressives all had hands in creating this thing. LUSE: For people who are seeing the continued stripping of the Voting Rights Act, for people who are thinking about the fact that most Americans support legalized access to abortion, and now, that's something that's not guaranteed by our Constitution anymore. MITCHELL: Yeah. LUSE: Many people feel like their rights are being stripped away. And I understand where you're coming from, where you say multiracial fascism is not a thing. I'm not necessarily saying that that's the proper term, but I'm trying to think about people who are going to be listening who might think, OK, well, if that's not fascism, then what is? What's a better descriptor? What's a better way to name this? MITCHELL: Cultural upheaval. I think we are in a period of intense cultural upheaval where the entire social contract is being relitigated. LUSE: I mean, I'll say, when you say cultural upheaval, that phrase is so neutral (laughter). And I think that, like, that makes sense, but I will say that when you say that to me, I understand why some people - regardless of where they are on the political spectrum - would reach for fascism, because social upheaval, it doesn't satisfy. It doesn't satisfy the feeling of fear and discomfort that I think many people feel when these big moments of change are happening. MITCHELL: I would agree. And I think that's why you see this term get used so much. I think being afraid and being anxious, those are - that is a normal reaction. That is not people overreacting because that is the environment into which, you know, European fascism emerged. But also, you know, it's the environment that the Civil Rights Movement really worked its power to force America to be a democracy. That is the actual outcome of the Civil Rights Movement. You know, I use the term cultural upheaval because these are tectonic shifts happening, you know, in the culture. And really, the question is, what's going to happen? How are people going to react? Because the government does not have the ability to just renegotiate the social contract. The entire culture is going to do that. LUSE: I have one last question. I mean, you know, even in the absence of total, you know, consensus regarding the characterization of our current political moment, because there are lots of people who feel like the country is moving in the right direction, what are people trying to point out or say when they return to the term fascism? What are they really trying to say? MITCHELL: Danger. Fascism as a meme, it is closely synonymous with danger. There is a threat, and it's an active threat. Because whenever you call someone a fascist or you call a group a fascist, you are not just saying that as a simple category of, oh, they just exist. No, like, these guys are trying to take something away from you. They are trying to repress you. So it's a recognition of there is danger, and it's coming after me. It's a ingrained alarm in American culture. And, you know, I think, despite all the changes and how it's been used in American history, it retains that sense of urgency that this is not something to sleep on. LUSE: Well, Nicholas, I really appreciate you sharing your knowledge with me today. I really, really got so much out of this conversation. Thank you so much. MITCHELL: Thank you for having me. LUSE: That was Professor Nicholas Ensley Mitchell. He teaches education theory, policy and practice at the University of Kansas. And I'm going to put on my influencer hat for a second and ask you to please subscribe to this show on Spotify, Apple or wherever you're listening. Click follow so you know the latest in culture while it's still hot. This episode of IT'S BEEN A MINUTE was produced by... ALEXIS WILLIAMS, BYLINE: Alexis Williams. BARTON GIRDWOOD, BYLINE: Barton Girdwood. LUSE: This episode was edited by... NEENA PATHAK, BYLINE: Neena Pathak. LUSE: Our executive producer is... VERALYN WILLIAMS, BYLINE: Veralyn Williams. LUSE: Our VP of programming is... YOLANDA SANGWENI, BYLINE: Yolanda Sangweni. LUSE: All right. That's all for this episode of IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR. I'm Brittany Luse. Talk soon.

articles.title: Better late than never: The delayed September jobs report will be out next week
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. Labor Department has delayed the release of its September jobs report — a critical economic indicator tracking employment trends and the unemployment rate — by nearly seven weeks, now scheduled for release on Thursday, November 21, 2025. The delay resulted from the government shutdown, which furloughed economists responsible for compiling the data, despite the data being already collected. This delay, along with the postponement of other key reports on October’s job gains, inflation, consumer spending, and GDP, leaves businesses, investors, and policymakers without timely economic data, increasing uncertainty about the strength or weakness of the U.S. economy. The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) has acknowledged public patience and plans to provide updated release schedules soon.
keyTakeAways: The U.S. Labor Department has delayed the release of the September jobs report by nearly seven weeks, originally scheduled for September, now set for release on Thursday, November 21, 2025.
The delay was caused by the government shutdown, which led to the furloughing of economists responsible for compiling the jobs data, even though the data was already collected.
The report details hiring, layoffs, and the unemployment rate for September and is one of the most closely watched economic indicators.
Other key economic reports, including those on October job gains, inflation, consumer spending, and GDP, are also delayed or still pending, creating uncertainty for businesses and policymakers.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) has acknowledged the public's patience and will provide an updated schedule for future reports as soon as possible.

articles.content:
Better late than never: The delayed September jobs report will be out next week 
         By Scott Horsley 
        
           Friday, November 14, 2025 • 4:34 PM EST 
        
        
      

         The Labor Department says it will release a key report on the September job market next Thursday, almost seven weeks behind schedule. The jobs report is one of many closely-watched economic indicators that were held up by the government shutdown.  The report — which details hiring, layoffs and the unemployment rate for September — was almost complete when the government economists who tally jobs were abruptly furloughed by the shutdown.  Since the data was already in hand, the report should be relatively easy to publish next week.  The timing of other key economic reports is still up in the air.  The government needs to conduct surveys and price checks before it can report on October's job gains and inflation rate.  Reports on consumer spending and GDP are also overdue, leaving businesses, investors and policymakers  looking for other clues  about the strength or weakness of the U.S. economy.   Government number-crunchers say they will post an updated schedule for other releases as soon as possible.  A  note on the BLS website  also thanks the public for its patience.

articles.title: Sirāt is a desert survival story — and one of the year's most gripping films
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The article reviews the film 'Sirāt', a 2025 survival drama directed by Oliver Laxe, which follows a father named Luis, played by Sergi López, as he searches for his missing daughter among a group of nomadic European ravers in southern Morocco during a post-apocalyptic world marked by the aftermath of a global crisis. The film blends elements of John Ford Westerns and post-apocalyptic cinema like 'Mad Max', yet stands out for its emotional sincerity and emphasis on human connection. Featuring non-professional actors recruited from rave events, the film is visually and sonically immersive, with a powerful score by Kangding Ray. It won a jury prize at the Cannes Film Festival and will represent Spain in the Academy Award race for Best International Feature Film. The narrative centers on themes of survival, loss, and compassion, contrasting the world's harshness with the enduring presence of kindness and family bonds.
keyTakeAways: The film 'Sirāt' is a survival story set in the Sahara Desert of southern Morocco, following a man named Luis and his son Esteban as they search for his missing daughter Mar among a group of nomadic European ravers after a global crisis.
The film is inspired by Islamic scripture, where 'sirāt' refers to a narrow bridge between Paradise and Hell, symbolizing the journey of survival and moral choice.
Director Oliver Laxe, a French-born Spanish filmmaker, employs non-professional actors recruited from rave events, lending authenticity to the off-grid, post-apocalyptic setting.
The movie draws comparisons to classic films like 'The Wages of Fear' and 'Sorcerer', but distinguishes itself through its emphasis on human compassion and relationships in the face of chaos.
'Sirāt' won a jury prize at the Cannes Film Festival and will represent Spain in the Academy Award race for Best International Feature Film.

articles.content:
'Sirāt' is a desert survival story — and one of the year's most gripping films 
         By Justin Chang 
        
           Friday, November 14, 2025 • 11:25 AM EST 
        
        
           Heard on  Fresh Air 
        
      

         The Arabic word  sirāt  means "path" or "way"; in Islamic scripture, it refers to a narrow bridge that connects Paradise and Hell. That makes it a fitting title for the director Oliver Laxe's new movie, which is both exhilarating and devastating.  Sirāt  is a survival story about several unlikely traveling companions making their way through a godforsaken stretch of the Sahara Desert. It carries echoes of countless earlier films, from the arid landscapes of a John Ford Western to the post-apocalyptic setting of  Mad Max . But nothing about  Sirāt  feels derivative or secondhand. It's an astonishing piece of cinema; I haven't had a more gripping experience in a movie theater all year. It begins somewhere in southern Morocco, where hundreds of nomadic European revelers have gathered for a rave. It seems that World War III or something like it has broken out, though the specifics are left vague. Whatever's going on,  Sirāt  initially plays like a party at the end of the world: Imagine a remake of the recent dystopian thriller  Civil War  set at  Burning Man , and you'll have some idea. Laxe, a French-born, Spanish director, sweeps you up in the intense physicality of the dancing and the propulsive beat of the music, composed by the experimental electronic musician Kangding Ray. Wandering around this unruly desert bacchanal is a middle-aged man named Luis, played by the Spanish actor Sergi López. This clearly isn't Luis' scene. Along with his young son Esteban and their dog, Luis is searching for his 20-something daughter, Mar, who vanished months ago, and whom he has reason to suspect is among the ravers.  But she's nowhere to be found, and before long, armed officials show up and, invoking a state of emergency, break up the party. Amid the ensuing chaos, five ravers drive off, bound for another rave further south. Luis and Esteban impulsively drive after them, hoping against hope that they'll find Mar. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       In Laxe's previous films, including the 2016 drama  Mimosas , which also chronicled a perilous journey through Morocco, he has worked mainly with non-professional actors. With the exception of López, that's also true here. The director recruited most of the principal cast from raves that he himself attended, and they're all naturals. I especially liked Stefania Gadda as a woman of few words but immense screen presence, and Jade Oukid as a dancer of mesmerizing ability. You feel for these off-the-grid daredevils, and you admire their survival tactics during what will prove to be an exceedingly dangerous trek. While the ravers have an enormous truck and a camper van, Luis and Esteban are in a small van that's ill-equipped for the treacherous terrain. But the ravers, somewhat reluctantly at first, let them tag along. They all share their limited resources, including food, water and gas. And they help each other out, when Luis has trouble fording a small river, or when the truck gets stuck on a steep mountain road.  Sirāt  is a visually and sonically overwhelming experience; it's full of majestic desert vistas and propelled by that thrillingly percussive score. It's also a drama of extraordinary tension and, eventually, shocking tragedy, in which death has a way of striking when you least expect it. I was often reminded of  The Wages of Fear  and  Sorcerer , two classic nail-biters, both adapted from a Georges Arnaud novel about a road trip from hell. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       What separates  Sirāt  from those two films, though, is its lack of cynicism. López is terrific as a father whose child has disappeared and who's understandably wary and mistrustful of the world. But even at his bleakest moments, Luis receives unexpected acts of compassion from his new companions.  At one point, Esteban asks one of the ravers if he misses his family, while traveling on the road, and the raver responds, "I prefer this family." That might sound like something Vin Diesel would say in a  Fast and Furious  movie, and as it happens, Diesel's driving skills might have come in handy here. But Laxe's film is as sincere in its tenderness as it is unrelenting in its ferocity. There's something powerful about the movie's belief that, even as an apocalypse looms, kindness can survive and meaningful relationships can form. Just because the world is pitiless,  Sirāt  suggests, doesn't mean that people have to be.

It's about a man searching for his lost daughter at a rave in the desert of southern Morocco. Imagine a remake of the recent dystopian thriller "Civil War" set at Burning Man and you'll have some idea. Laxe sweeps you up in the intense physicality of the dancing and the propulsive beat of the music, composed by the experimental electronic musician Kangding Ray. (SOUNDBITE OF FILM, "SIRAT") CHANG: Wandering around this unruly desert bacchanal is a middle-aged man named Luis, played by the Spanish actor Sergi Lopez. This clearly isn't Luis' scene. Along with his young son, Esteban, and their dog, Luis is searching for his 20-something daughter, Mar, who vanished months ago and whom he has reason to suspect is among the ravers. But she's nowhere to be found. And before long, armed officials show up, and invoking a state of emergency, break up the party. Amid the ensuing chaos, five ravers drive off, bound for another rave further south. Luis and Esteban impulsively drive after them, hoping against hope that they'll find Mar. In Laxe's previous films, including the 2016 drama "Mimosas," which also chronicled a perilous journey through Morocco, he has worked mainly with nonprofessional actors. With the exception of Sergi Lopez, that's also true here. The director recruited most of the principal cast from raves that he himself attended, and they're all naturals. I especially like Stefania Gadda as a woman of few words but immense screen presence, and Jade Oukid as a dancer of mesmerizing ability. You feel for these off-the-grid daredevils, and you admire their survival tactics during what will prove to be an exceedingly dangerous trek. While the ravers have an enormous truck and a camper van, Luis and Esteban are in a small van that's ill-equipped for the treacherous terrain. But the ravers, somewhat reluctantly at first, let them tag along. They all share their limited resources, including food, water and gas. And they help each other out when Luis has trouble fording a small river, or when the truck gets stuck on a steep mountain road. "Sirat" is a visually and sonically overwhelming experience. It's full of majestic desert vistas and propelled by that thrillingly percussive score. It's also a drama of extraordinary tension, and eventually, shocking tragedy, in which death has a way of striking when you least expect it. I was often reminded of "The Wages Of Fear" and "Sorcerer," two classic nail-biters, both adapted from a Georges Arnaud novel about a road trip from hell. What separates "Sirat" from those two films, though, is its lack of cynicism. Lopez is terrific as a father whose child has disappeared and who's understandably wary and mistrustful of the world. But even at his bleakest moments, Luis receives unexpected acts of compassion from his new companions. At one point, Esteban asks one of the ravers if he misses his family while traveling on the road. And the raver responds, I prefer this family. That might sound like something Vin Diesel would say in a "Fast & Furious" movie, and as it happens, Diesel's driving skills might've come in handy here. But Laxe's film is as sincere in its tenderness as it is unrelenting in its ferocity. There's something powerful about the movie's belief that even as an apocalypse looms, kindness can survive and meaningful relationships can form. Just because the world is pitiless, "Sirat" suggests, doesn't mean that people have to be. BIANCULLI: Justin Chang is a film critic at The New Yorker. He reviewed "Sirat," now playing in select theaters. On Monday's show, actress and singer Cynthia Erivo. She returns on screen as Elphaba in "Wicked: For Good," who claims her own power even as the world deems her the wicked witch. In Erivo's new memoir, "Simply More," she explores similar themes, shedding other people's definitions of who she should be as a woman and an artist. I hope you can join us. (SOUNDBITE OF SONG, "DEFYING GRAVITY") CYNTHIA ERIVO: (Singing) Something has changed within me. Something is not the same. I'm through with playing by the rules of someone else's game. Too late for second-guessing. Too late to go back to sleep. It's time to trust my instincts, close my eyes and leap. It's time to try defying gravity. I think I'll try defying gravity, and you can't pull me down. BIANCULLI: To keep up with what's on the show and get highlights of our interviews, follow us on Instagram at @nprfresh Air. And you can subscribe to our YouTube channel at youtube.com/thisfreshair. We're rolling out new videos with in-studio guests, behind-the-scenes shorts and iconic interviews from the archive. (SOUNDBITE OF SLOWBERN'S "DING DONG DITCH") BIANCULLI: FRESH AIR's executive producer is Danny Miller. Sam Briger is our managing producer. Our senior producer today is Roberta Shorrock. Our technical director and engineer is Audrey Bentham, with additional engineering support by Joyce Lieberman, Julian Herzfeld and Diana Martinez. Our interviews and reviews are produced and edited by Phyllis Myers, Ann Marie Baldonado, Lauren Krenzel, Therese Madden, Monique Nazareth, Thea Chaloner, Susan Nyakundi and Anna Bauman. Our digital media producer is Molly Seavy-Nesper. Hope Wilson is our consulting visual producer. For Terry Gross and Tonya Mosley, I'm David Bianculli. (SOUNDBITE OF SLOWBERN'S "DING DONG DITCH")

articles.content:
This week brings new books grappling with the endings of relationships and eras 
         By Colin Dwyer 
        
           Tuesday, November 11, 2025 • 10:40 AM EST 
        
        
      

         It feels fitting, in a way, that so many notable books this week are premised on endings — of lives, relationships, eras, even. After all, Armistice Day, or Remembrance Day — also known as Veterans Day in the U.S. – is Tuesday. The day annually  marks the end  of one of history's most catastrophic conflicts, World War I. For the most part, the endings that animate many of this week's new novels don't seek such world-historical consequence. Ann Packer, Quiara Alegria Hudes and the other authors who grace the list below are concerned with much more intimate details, the kind you're more likely to encounter just down the street than on a battlefield or at an international summit. That said, the twisty history of currency — the subject of this week's one nonfiction entry in the roundup — reinforces a lesson learned with the peace of 1918: Beware of endings; they have the odd habit of being yet another beginning in disguise. Some Bright Nowhere , by Ann Packer Ann Packer's first novel in a decade finds the American author again pursuing a deceptively simple premise: A long-married couple must prepare for and confront their final weeks together before death comes for one of them. But don't be fooled by the saccharine-sounding summary. As  Fresh Air 's Maureen Corrigan explained in  a review of Packer's previous novel ,  The Children's Crusade , the author has a knack for turning what might have been "mundane mass-market fiction" into a rich, splintered narrative that "illuminate[s] the unexpected depths of the commonplace." The White Hot , by Quiara Alegria Hudes It's possible you've already encountered Hudes' writing without knowing it. Though her name is new to the adult fiction shelf, the veteran playwright penned the book for the Tony-winning musical  In the Heights ,  wrote the screenplay  for  its 2021 film adaptation  and won the 2012 Pulitzer Prize for  her play  Water by the Spoonful , about the return of an Iraq war veteran. In  The White Hot ,  she explores a departure , in the voice of a young mother who tries to understand and explain her decision to leave her family for the freedom of a one-way ticket far, far away. The Silver Book , by Olivia Laing Laing's writing roams a Venn diagram of memoir, art criticism, history and fiction, rarely pursuing just one genre without including at least some elements of the others. Her memoir  The Lonely City , for instance, wove the stuff of academic journals into a  chronicle of her life in New York City . Her only previous novel,  Crudo , dressed up in the persona of author Kathy Acker for an exercise that NPR's reviewer admiringly called a "memoir in drag." For its part,  The Silver Book , though a novel, sets its inventions in an especially consequential – and controversial – era of Italian cinema: the final year or two before the brutal, unsolved murder of director Pier Paolo Pasolini. Evensong , by Stewart O'Nan O'Nan's latest novel finds the "oracle of the ordinary and maven of the middle class" — as NPR reviewer Heller McAlpin  described the novelist in 2012  — once again mining the mundane for its hidden magic. In  Evensong , the cult favorite centers a small, lovingly rendered group of older women as they navigate the peculiar challenges of growing older, together as friends. The History of Money: A Story of Humanity , by David McWilliams McWilliams is an Irish economist,  podcaster  and founder of a festival that  pairs world economics with standup comedy . Promoting the festival back in 2010, McWilliams  explained to NPR  why he orients his work more toward the hoi polloi than the ivory tower: "If you think that knowledge is power, well, then giving people the knowledge, packaging the knowledge in such a way that the knowledge becomes accessible — that empowers the people." That rings true in this lively, lightfooted life story of currency, which cares less for comprehensiveness than keeping the door open for experts and novices alike.

articles.title: Ken Burns' 'American Revolution' will make you think differently about U.S. history
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Ken Burns' new six-part documentary, 'The American Revolution,' offers a deeply immersive and nuanced exploration of the Revolutionary War, utilizing innovative visual techniques such as drone footage and close-ups of re-enactors' bodies to create authenticity without period photographs. The series, written by Geoffrey C. Ward and co-directed by Sarah Botstein and David Schmidt, goes beyond traditional narratives by incorporating voices of Native Americans, revolutionary women, enslaved people, and Loyalists, providing a more inclusive and humanized account of the conflict. Through animated maps and detailed battle analysis, it emphasizes the scale and complexity of the war, challenging the viewer's understanding of American history and reminding audiences that the pursuit of a more perfect union remains an ongoing effort.
keyTakeAways: Ken Burns' 'The American Revolution' offers a nuanced, detailed, and immersive portrayal of the Revolutionary War, challenging traditional narratives by centering marginalized voices such as Native Americans, revolutionary women, and enslaved people.

The documentary uses innovative techniques like drone footage and close-ups of re-enactors' bodies (e.g., bandaged hands, muddy boots) to create a visceral and authentic experience without relying on period photographs.
It emphasizes individual battles and troop movements through animated maps, offering a level of detail not typically found in standard U.S. history curricula.

The narrative balances perspectives from military leaders like George Washington and Benjamin Franklin with those of Loyalists and Patriots, humanizing both sides and explaining motivations such as tribal land protection.

The documentary is part of Ken Burns' long-standing legacy of redefining American history through evocative storytelling, music, and sound design, including previous works like 'The Civil War' and 'The Congress'.

articles.content:
Ken Burns' 'American Revolution' will make you think differently about U.S. history 
         By David Bianculli 
        
           Wednesday, November 12, 2025 • 12:02 PM EST 
        
        
           Heard on  Fresh Air 
        
      

         Documentary producer and director  Ken Burns  came to prominence 35 years ago with  The Civil War,  a massively popular multi-part nonfiction series on PBS.   His latest effort is a six-part series called  The American Revolution. By focusing on the Revolutionary War ,  Burns is revisiting some very familiar territory. His long and impressive filmography includes a history of Congress, and biographies of Thomas Jefferson and Benjamin Franklin. He's done deep dives into American military conflicts, including  World War II  and the  Vietnam War . Throughout his career, Burns has developed and perfected the tricks of his particular trade: the evocative use of music and quotations from speeches and correspondence; the use of actors to read the words of historical participants; the zooming in and out to reveal key details in period photos; and the painstaking attention to sound effects, from birds to bullets, to help bring those images to life. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       All of that knowledge, and all of those gimmicks, are utilized in  The American Revolution , an exceptional work about the founding of our country. It's written by Geoffrey C. Ward, who wrote  The Civil War  and many other Burns documentaries, including the ones on Congress and Thomas Jefferson. And it's co-directed by Sarah Botstein and David Schmidt, both of whom have worked with Burns for years. But  The American Revolution  presents a challenge that even  The Civil War  did not. No photographs, period. To compensate, Burns and company use war re-enactors and place them in the actual historical locations.  
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       On many — let's say most — documentaries using a similar technique, the effect can be cheesy. But in  The American Revolution,  the directors avoid showing the faces of the actors re-enacting battle movements. Instead, parts of their bodies are shown in intense close-up: a bandaged hand here, a muddy boot there. Elsewhere, in an approach that borders on pure art, the directors use drones to capture the action from high, high above. It's unusual — and beautiful. Battles are the surprisingly dominant ingredient of this series.  The American Revolution  goes into more detail about individual battles than I ever learned in my own American history classes — but new and vintage maps, animated to show troop positions and movements, make it all very clear, and very vibrant. The actors quoting from the historical participants, and the historians interviewed to comment on the action, do the rest. Peter Coyote, the actor who has narrated many Burns documentaries, does so again here. He's got a great voice for it, and leans into all the difficult place names, and people's names, with confident authority.  
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       In their various war documentaries, Burns and his team always have focused as much on the ground troops as on the generals — often much more so, telling their story from the bottom up, rather than the top down.  The American Revolution  does both: We hear important observations from George Washington and Benjamin Franklin, but also from Native Americans, revolutionary women, enslaved people and others not always given voice in such narratives.  In addition, the program's historians make us think differently about the history we're witnessing. In the colonies, those who were faithful to the crown were called Loyalists, and those against them called themselves Patriots. This series humanizes both sides, and also explains why some Native tribes, including the Shawnees, sided with the British in hopes of protecting their own lands.  The sheer number of the battles, and the details about them, attest to how hard our ancestors fought for the notion of a Federalist society. At the end,  The American Revolution  reminds us that the quest to maintain that society, and to strive to achieve a more perfect union, is far from over.

articles.content:
'The Running Man,' a new 'Now You See Me,' and George Clooney are in theaters 
         By Bob Mondello, Linda Holmes 
        
           Friday, November 14, 2025 • 11:38 AM EST 
        
        
      

         There's yet another  Now You See Me  in theaters this weekend, along with yet another Stephen King adaptation. George Clooney plays a charming Hollywood star in Jay Kelly, while a warm, funny and goosebump-raising documentary streams on Apple TV. Here's what to watch. Now You See Me, Now You Don't In theaters Friday  
       
       Youtube Video 
       The cast keeps expanding in this magic-centric rob-from-the-rich-give-to-the-poor heist franchise, as if the writers saw  Ocean's Eleven  through  Thirteen  and thought, "we could do that." New kids Justice Smith, Dominic Sessa and Ariana Greenblatt join original Horsemen (and hangers-on) Jesse Eisenberg, Woody Harrelson, Dave Franco, Morgan Freeman and Isla Fisher in pursuit of a priceless diamond held by a money-laundering arms dealer (Rosamund Pike). That fits the aesthetic of the first two  Now You See Me' s (shouldn't this one really be called  Now You Three Me ?) — but where the earlier films seemed to want you to believe the on-screen magicians were pulling off their tricks, this one mostly settles for CGI and cinematic trickery, so that even card tricks fall slightly flat. Eisenberg's prickly snark is still fun, but with the tricks getting less convincing and the scripts more exhausting, it might be time for this franchise to go up in a puff of smoke.  — Bob Mondello  The Running Man  In theaters Friday  This trailer includes instances of vulgar language.  
       
       Youtube Video 
       One tricky thing about writing dystopian fiction with staying power is that the future eventually catches up with you. Stephen King's 1982 novel  The Running Man  takes place in 2025. In his vision of, well, now, there is widespread poverty, rule by giant corporations, and exploitative entertainment that takes advantage of people who are suffering and tries to force ordinary people to despise each other. There is environmental destruction, mass surveillance, and even the resurgence of polio. Just imagine. The story follows a man named Ben Richards, who tries to provide for his family and his sick kid by going on a game show also called  The Running Man . On the show, he has to survive on the streets for 30 days while professional assassins pursue him. If he makes it, he wins a billion dollars. But, of course, nobody has ever survived. In the new adaptation, directed by Edgar Wright, Richards (played by Glen Powell) auditions for the game shows run by the megacorporation known as The Network because his daughter has the flu, and Richards and his wife can't afford a doctor for her without a big prize. The biggest problem with this adaptation is that if you read the book, you probably know there are a couple of things about the ending that a major studio movie released in 2025 is unlikely to replicate. As an action movie that hits the gas, gets the running man running, and doesn't let up, it works quite well, and it's a lot of fun. But some of King's sharper-elbowed commentary about what it might take to escape this kind of oppressive society is blunted a bit, making it a less effective critique of its world than the book was.  — Linda Holmes  Jay Kelly In limited theaters Friday; on Netflix Dec. 5 
       
       Youtube Video 
       Hollywood star Jay Kelly — handsome, affable, debonaire, sixty-something … in short, George Clooney — reconsiders his life choices on a trip to Tuscany in Noah Baumbach's bland mid-life crisis dramedy. Estranged from one daughter (Riley Keough), and distressed by the growing distance of another (Grace Edwards) who's off on a trip to Europe before college, he's feeling alone in a crowd of paid companions, including his faithful manager (Adam Sandler, excellent) and publicist (Laura Dern, whose talents are mostly wasted). After a public altercation with a college buddy, he opts to avoid the PR blowup and possibly find some catch-up time with his daughter by taking an impromptu trip to Italy for a career tribute he'd previously turned down.  Minor misadventures ensue — a train trip punctuated by a purse snatching incident, a reunion with his coarse dad (Stacy Keach), a fight with his increasingly put-upon manager. Not sure I was feeling anyone's pain about the loneliness of stardom, the heartbreak of success, the … whatever the hell else this was about. Baumbach has wandered into the territory of  8½  and  Stardust Memories  and he gets a bit lost in the woods, but Clooney's magnetism goes a decent way to making things palatable, the cinematography is pretty and Sandler dominates whenever he's on screen.  — Bob Mondello  The Things You Kill In limited theaters Friday  
       
       Youtube Video 
       Iranian-Canadian director Alireza Khatami's Turkish-language thriller follows Ali, a university professor, as his life unravels. His mother's sick, his father's a bully, his wife wants a child (he hasn't told her his sperm count is low), and his only safe place is an arid farm ("garden") to which he retreats whenever possible. The arrival of Reza, a stranger who is game to do the things Ali won't (bribe bureaucrats to deepen his well, maybe even kill his father) complicates things, and also, in a sense, solves them. The filmmaker's first name provides a not-insignificant clue as to what's going on, as his filmmaking deconstructs the story and his protagonist in initially confusing, and then riveting ways.  — Bob Mondello Come See Me In the Good Light Streaming on Apple TV starting Friday 
       
       Youtube Video 
       There's no way to make this documentary sound like the upbeat, rousing and often downright hilarious romp it is, but here goes: At the urging of comedian Tig Notaro, poet and spoken-word star Andrea Gibson and life partner and fellow poet Megan Falley invited filmmaker Ryan White and his crew into their home in 2021. It was mid-pandemic, and the crew was allowed full access to the couple's every thought and action as they dealt with turtledove love, mailbox madness, and – here's the part where you say, "no, this does not sound like a good time" — Gibson's Stage 4 ovarian cancer journey. At the Middleburg Film Festival screening I attended in October — three months after Gibson's death — the director spoke beforehand, giving the audience "permission to laugh," which it definitely did. It also sniffled a bit, but less than you might expect, because Gibson's vibrant, assertively affirmative outlook doesn't really brook tears, and the filmmaker's warmth and humor, even in times of despair, gives the story a radiance that makes mundane moments feel precious, while allowing hopeful moments to raise goosebumps.  — Bob Mondello

articles.title: Dear Life Kit: I'm tall. How do I politely ask people to stop bringing it up?
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The article features three real-life questions answered by NPR's Dear Life Kit, which is an advice column led by clinical psychologist Adia Gooden and host Brittany Luse. The first question addresses how a tall woman can handle unwanted comments about her height, with advice to respond playfully and then directly if necessary. The second explores how couples can communicate their decision to delay marriage due to financial concerns, using gentle and respectful language. The third deals with a woman who feels judged by her future sister-in-law, emphasizing the importance of setting personal boundaries and recognizing when someone’s opinions are harmful. The column emphasizes emotional self-awareness, boundary-setting, and respectful communication in personal relationships, offering practical, empathetic guidance for everyday social challenges.
keyTakeAways: People often comment on a tall woman's height, which can feel like being a spectacle rather than a compliment.
A suggested response is to playfully deflect with, 'Oh my gosh, you're the first person to tell me that,' allowing a gentle, non-confrontational laugh.
If the comment persists, a more direct response like 'It's not cool. I'm not comfortable with it. Please stop' can be used to establish boundaries.
In relationships, couples may feel pressure to marry early, especially from family, but can communicate intentionality by stating financial considerations and a desire to avoid debt.
A lighter approach, such as 'I don't have any updates to share right now, but when I do, you'll be the first to know,' can manage expectations without rudeness.
When facing judgmental or hurtful comments from family, such as a sister-in-law calling someone self-absorbed, one should recognize the difference between constructive feedback and harmful judgment.
It is important to set boundaries, such as saying, 'I feel judged when you give me advice. So I prefer that not to be part of our relationship.'
In relationships with judgmental family members, partners can work together to manage the dynamic, and it may be necessary to accept that the person may never change.
Individuals should decide which opinions to accept and which to ignore, maintaining self-worth and emotional well-being.

articles.content:
Dear Life Kit: I'm tall. How do I politely ask people to stop bringing it up? 
         By Andee Tagle, Sylvie Douglis, Beck Harlan 
        
           Friday, November 14, 2025 • 5:00 AM EST 
        
        
      

        
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Dear Life Kit  is NPR's advice column, where experts answer tricky questions about relationships, social etiquette, work culture and more. Have a question you want to ask Dear Life Kit anonymously?  Share it here.   These questions were answered by Adia Gooden, a clinical psychologist and host of the podcast  Unconditionally Worthy ,  and NPR's Brittany Luse, host of    It's Been a Minute .  The conversation has been edited for length and clarity. Dear Life Kit, I'm a six-foot-tall woman, and both complete strangers and new acquaintances often make comments like, 'Wow, you're tall.' Some people say I should take it as a compliment, but it makes me feel like a spectacle. I don't want to normalize the comments, but I also don't want to embarrass the commenters. How can I respond? —  More than my height   Brittany Luse:  I appreciate the fact that you don't want to embarrass people. I want to offer the idea of maybe not 100% embarrassment or even 60% embarrassment, but a nice, gritty little 15% embarrassment. You can respond with, 'Oh my gosh, you're the first person to tell me that.' Give them a little giggle. Give them the opportunity to laugh with you, but they know you're not playing. And if they don't take the hint the first time, you can be direct. 'Is this catching your attention so much that you have to say something right now?' I think you can give someone one pass with a little joke to let them know you don't like it. And then after that, be really direct. Adia Gooden:  I agree.  If people continue to cross this boundary, be more serious about it. You can say, 'It's not cool. I'm not comfortable with it. Please stop.' If somebody feels a little embarrassed and realizes they shouldn't have said that, that's OK. You're not saying they're an awful person, but you're communicating that what they did is problematic. They should feel a little taste of it so that they stop. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Dear Life Kit, I've been with my boyfriend for seven years. I'm starting to feel pressure from family members and friends to settle down and have a wedding. We're planning to get married, but we want to wait until we are more financially secure. How can I let people know we're not in a hurry to get married without being rude? —  Not in a hurry Gooden:  If people are coming from a loving place, just say, 'We're being really intentional about how we want to start the next chapter of our lives together. Weddings are expensive. We don't want to start our lives together in debt or going into debt.' Luse:   When I was in a similar situation, I would say, 'If you've got tens of thousands of dollars that you want to give me, go right ahead.' Or the other, mildly gentler, response, 'I don't have any updates to share right now, but when I do, you'll be the first to know.' Which is what I say now when people ask me about having children. Gooden:  [If a lighter touch doesn't work,] you can just say, 'Please stop asking us. It's kind of frustrating when you keep asking us about our plans. We will be sure to let you know when we are going in that direction, but until then, please respect our decision-making.' 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Dear Life Kit, My future sister-in-law often says things that are hurtful or judgmental. She once told me, 'I love you, but you're too self-absorbed to own a dog.' And this was over a meal that I brought over for her. I've had pets, raised my younger sister and taken care of my sick mom. I don't think most people would consider me self-absorbed. Her comments bring my fiancé and me down. I've begun avoiding her. How can I cope in a healthy way and still have a relationship with her? —  Feeling frozen? Gooden:  This might be a situation where you need to recognize when someone's comments are not about you. If you know that you're not self-absorbed, then you shouldn't let somebody's comment derail you or override what you know to be true about yourself. So, how do you stay grounded in who you are? You need to discern whose opinion you're going to take and whose opinion you're going to leave. If your wise grandma says, 'Hey, it seems like you've been focusing on yourself a little too much, and I want you to think about this.' That might be different than a comment from a sister-in-law who tends to make judgmental comments. She may be somebody whose opinion you're going to ignore. You may also need to set some boundaries. For example, 'Hey, I feel judged when you give me advice. So I prefer that not to be part of our relationship.' Luse:  At the end of the day, this is your fiancé's sister, and I wonder if he could play a bigger role in managing your relationship with her as a couple. It sounds like maybe he's also feeling the impact of her judgment. I'll share something my therapist said to me once when I was navigating a difficult relationship: 'Have you ever considered that this person may never change? I want you to consider that, and then think about how you want to conduct yourself going forward.' You can't control her. You can only control how and when you interact with her, to a certain degree. The podcast episode was hosted by Andee Tagle and produced by Sylvie Douglis. The digital and visual editor was Beck Harlan. We'd love to hear from you. Leave us a voicemail at 202-216-9823, or email us at LifeKit@npr.org. Listen to Life Kit on  Apple Podcasts  and  Spotify , and sign up for our  newsletter . Follow us on Instagram:  @nprlifekit .

articles.title: Pack Fire Damages 15 Structures, Forces Evacuations in Mono County, California
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A fast-moving wildfire known as the Pack Fire erupted in Mono County, California, near the Nevada state border, damaging 15 structures, prompting evacuations, and forcing the temporary closure of Highway 395. The fire, which grew to about 5.3 square miles by Thursday night, was driven by strong winds up to 50 mph, temporarily grounding emergency aircraft. Fire activity decreased due to precipitation, and firefighting crews continued operations through the night. Evacuation shelters were set up at a middle school and the Tri-County Fairgrounds. The cause of the fire is under investigation, and while the RV park in McGee Creek was impacted, it remains unclear whether any homes were destroyed. The rural, mountainous region of Mono County—known for its scenic lakes, pine forests, and proximity to the Sierra Nevada—is particularly vulnerable to such events, emphasizing the broader implications of climate and wildfire risks in remote, forested areas.

MONO COUNTY, Calif. (AP) — A fast-moving wildfire in a picturesque California county along the Nevada state border has damaged 15 structures, prompted evacuations and forced the closure of part of a highway on Thursday as firefighters worked to contain it in the face of strong winds. The Pack Fire in Mono County, about 140 miles (225.3 kilometers) southeast of Sacramento, had grown to about 5.3 square miles (13.7 square kilometers) by Thursday night and was burning without any containment, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection, or Cal Fire. The blaze had been whipped up by gusts as strong as 50 miles per hour (80.5 kilometers per hour) that temporarily grounded emergency aircraft, according to Cal Fire. But by Thursday evening, the department said in a statement, “Fire activity has decreased due to precipitation in the area.” “Crews will work through the night; additional resources are arriving tomorrow,” according to Cal Fire. Part of Highway 395 was temporarily closed and an RV park in McGee Creek had been “impacted,” but it was unclear whether any homes had been destroyed. articles.title: The best games of 2025 so far, picked by NPR's staff
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In mid-2025, NPR staff compiled a list of the best video games released so far, highlighting both major franchises and independent titles. The year saw the launch of the Nintendo Switch 2 and blockbuster exclusives like Mario Kart World, while also witnessing significant industry challenges such as labor strikes and layoffs. Among the standout titles are the indie puzzle game Blue Prince, praised for its intricate puzzle design and narrative depth; Death Stranding 2, lauded as a deeply emotional and thought-provoking walking simulator by Hideo Kojima; and Clair Obscur: Expedition 33, celebrated for its exceptional storytelling, character development, and layered narrative that rewards multiple playthroughs. These selections reflect a broader cultural shift in how video games are perceived—no longer just entertainment, but a medium for art, empathy, and complex worldbuilding.
keyTakeAways: The year 2025 saw the release of the Nintendo Switch 2 and blockbuster exclusives such as Mario Kart World.
A surge of indie game breakouts emerged, including Blue Prince and Clair Obscur: Expedition 33.

NPR staff and contributors highlighted a diverse range of games, from puzzle games and sequels like Death Stranding 2 to narrative-driven titles like Molly House and Daggerheart.
Death Stranding 2, despite being labeled a 'walking simulator' by critics, is praised for its emotional and narrative depth, prompting players to reflect on human connection and terrain management.
Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is lauded as a masterpiece of storytelling, with rich character development, strong writing, and layered narrative complexity that rewards repeated playthroughs.

articles.content:
The best games of 2025 so far, picked by NPR's staff 
         By James Perkins Mastromarino 
        
           Wednesday, July 16, 2025 • 7:00 AM EDT 
        
        
      

         2025 finally brought the release of the  Nintendo Switch 2  and blockbuster exclusives like Mario Kart World. But the year has also seen a parade of indie breakouts, from Blue Prince to Clair Obscur: Expedition 33. Meanwhile, the video game industry lurched from  massive strikes  to  landmark labor deals  to  deep layoffs . NPR staff and contributors have explored the breadth of the gaming year, from long-awaited sequels like Death Stranding 2 and Fatal Fury: City of the Wolves to imaginative tabletop games like Molly House and Daggerheart. Whether you're looking for a short diversion or an epic 50-hour adventure, we invite you to discover your next favorite game on this interactive list. 
         
         Transcript 
         MARY LOUISE KELLY, HOST:   Let's talk video games now. We are only in July, and already there have been some great game releases this year. So we've asked some of our NPR colleagues to share their favorites. First game up, an indie puzzle game called Blue Prince. GRAHAM REBHUN, BYLINE: My name is Graham Rebhun, and I am a software engineer on the publishing team at NPR. It's one of those crazy puzzle games that always seems to have another thread that you haven't pulled on yet. You're basically exploring this huge mansion that your rich uncle left to you, and each room you open has unique activities, resources to grab and hints and clues about how everything in the house works and how you fit into the story that's being told through all of the letters and notes and things around the house. By the time I finished the first part of the game - and yes, there are many layers to Blue Prince - I had several notebook pages filled with notes and diagrams, which, for me, is the sign of a good puzzle game. KELLY: Next, we're going to hear about a highly anticipated sequel from gaming legend Hideo Kojima. ANGEL CARRERAS, BYLINE: Death Stranding 2 is a very stupid game, and I mean that in the most endearing way possible. (SOUNDBITE OF VIDEO GAME, "DEATH STRANDING 2: ON THE BEACH") UNIDENTIFIED VOICE ACTOR: (As character) This is the cargo you need to deliver. Be sure to get it to its destination in one piece. It's an excellent idea to place the most important cargo in your backpack. CARRERAS: My name is Angel Carreras. I'm a assistant producer at NPR. This whole game, people call it a walking simulator - derogatory. This is actually a positive thing. I think it's - what game is going to have you think about terrain and the lives of people and the things you're bringing them? Never before have I been like, oh, my God, I got to get this medicine to these people, or I got to deliver this pizza to this poor guy. And on top of that, you're fighting these, like, beings that are crossing from death into our world. And it's just - I don't know, man. You just have to play it yourself. That's really all I can say. KELLY: OK. So if you are maybe looking for a game with a more epic storyline, you can try Clair Obscur: Expedition 33. KAITY KLINE, BYLINE: I'm Kaity Kline. I'm an associate producer with Morning Edition and Up First. It's like, when people say, like, video games are art, I think that they specifically mean games like this. (SOUNDBITE OF VIDEO GAME, "CLAIR OBSCUR: EXPEDITION 33") BILLIE FULFORD-BROWN: (As Sophie) You're fighting to change things. KLINE: There's not one thing about the game that I can pinpoint as my absolute favorite because I think it's just, like, perfection across the board. I think the characters are so well developed. I think the writing is so good. The art, the fighting, the - just, like, everything - the story, the plot. And, like, I almost never restart a game as soon as I finish it. But for this one, I wiped my tears and just immediately started over because I think there's so many things that you didn't notice your first playthrough that suddenly have so much meaning the second go around, and I wanted to just see every little thing that I missed. Yeah. It's like, just wherever you think the story is going to go, you're wrong. KELLY: We have got tons more video game recommendations from our staff and some tabletop games, too. You can check out our full mid-2025 games roundup at . (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

articles.title: Epstein’s Global Network: Emails Reveal Enduring Ties to Politicians, Academics, and Business Leaders
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A series of emails released by the House Oversight Committee reveal the extensive and enduring network of influential individuals—including politicians, academics, and business leaders—connected to Jeffrey Epstein after his 2008 conviction. The correspondence spans from 2009 to 2019, showing Epstein’s continued engagement with figures across political ideologies, such as Noam Chomsky and Steve Bannon, and offering advice on political strategy, personal relationships, and crisis management. While the emails do not implicate these contacts in Epstein’s crimes, they highlight the depth and global reach of his influence, even as a registered sex offender. The revelations underscore the complexity of power networks and raise questions about accountability, access, and the role of personal connections in politics and business.
keyTakeAways: Jeffrey Epstein maintained a global network of high-profile individuals including politicians, business leaders, academics, and activists, even after his 2008 conviction.
Epstein’s emails reveal ongoing political and personal connections, such as advising Steve Bannon and offering advice to Noam Chomsky and Laurence Krauss on handling allegations of sexual misconduct.
The emails demonstrate that Epstein was actively involved in political strategy, such as advising on European tours and suggesting introductions to foreign leaders.
Epstein engaged with figures across ideological lines, including liberal academic Noam Chomsky and conservative ally Steve Bannon, indicating a broad, cross-aligned influence.

Some contacts, like Larry Summers and Boris Nikolic, openly acknowledged their interactions with Epstein, with Summers expressing regret and Krauss stating he sought advice during a harassment scandal.
The network’s continued activity post-conviction underscores the complexity of power dynamics and the role of personal connections in politics and business.
